com.google.appinventor.components.runtime.util

Class OrientationSensorUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.appinventor.components.runtime.util.OrientationSensorUtil

  • public class OrientationSensorUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    Functionality related to OrientationSensor, placed in this static utility class for easier testing.

    • Method Detail

      • mod

        static float mod(float dividend,
                 float quotient)
        Computes the modulo relationship. This is not the same as Java's remainder (%) operation, which always returns a value with the same sign as the dividend or 0.
        Parameters:
        dividend - number to divide
        quotient - number to divide by
        Returns:
        the number r with the smallest absolute value such that sign(r) == sign(quotient) and there exists an integer k such that k * quotient + r = dividend

      • normalizeAzimuth

        public static float normalizeAzimuth(float azimuth)
        Normalizes azimuth to be in the range [0, 360).
        Parameters:
        azimuth - an angle in degrees, likely to be in (-360, +360)
        Returns:
        an equivalent angle in the range [0, 360)

      • normalizePitch

        public static float normalizePitch(float pitch)
        Normalizes pitch to be in the range [-180, +180).
        Parameters:
        pitch - an angle in degrees, likely to be in (-360, +360)
        Returns:
        an equivalent angle in the range [-180, +180)

      • normalizeRoll

        public static float normalizeRoll(float roll)
        Normalizes roll to be in the range [-90, +90] degrees. The App Inventor definition of Roll in the documentation is:
        0 degrees when the device is level, increasing to 90 degrees as the device is tilted up onto its left side, and decreasing to -90 degrees when the device is tilted up onto its right side.
        After rotating the phone more than 90 degrees, Roll decreased. For compatibility, we are guaranteeing the same behavior.
        Parameters:
        roll - an angle likely to be in the range [-180, +180]
        Returns:
        the equivalent angle in the range [-90, +90], where angles with an absolute value greater than 90 are reflected over the x-axis; the value is not defined for inputs outside of [-180, +180]
